questions.text:
Pick out the true statements regarding reference for Indian man and woman in the latest NIN-RDA guidelines.


	The age group considered is 19-39 for both men and women.
	According to the guidelines Ideal weight of an Indian man is 60 kgs and woman is 50kgs
	The guideline requires a person to rest for at least 8 hours daily.
	The guideline promotes not more than 10 hours of intense work every day.
	At Least 2 hours of recreational activities are mandated.
	The ideal BMI for men and women is 20-21 kg/m².
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1, 3, 5 & 6

Explanation:

The standard reference for Indian Man and woman in the latest NIN-RDA guidelines is used to calculate the ideal amount of energy and protein a person requires. (NIN- National Institute of Nutrition, RDA- Recommended dietary allowance)

Category

Reference Man

Reference Woman

Age (Point A)

19-39 years

19-39 years

Weight (Point B)

65 kg

55 kg

Height

177 cm

162 cm

BMI (Point F)

20.74 kg/m²

20.95 kg/m²

BMI (Asian Classification)

18.5 - 22.9 kg/m²

Protein Requirement

0.83 g/kg/day

Visible Fat Intake

25 g/day (Sedentary)

20 g/day (Sedentary)

30 g/day (Moderate)

25 g/day (Moderate)

40 g/day (Heavy)

30 g/day (Heavy)

Activity Level
  • 8 hours of sleep (Point C)
  • 8 hours of moderate work (Point D)
  • 4-6 hours of sitting/moving
  • 2 hours of walking/recreation (Point E)

questions.text:
Priya is an Indian woman who weighs 60 kilograms. Calculate her daily protein requirement and determine which of the following dietary plans meets her protein needs (Protein in every meal is given in grams)

 


	
		
			
			MEAL
			
			
			PLAN A
			
			
			PLAN B
			
			
			PLAN C
			
			
			PLAN D
			
		
		
			
			Breakfast
			
			
			2 eggs (12g)
			
			
			1 banana (1g)
			
			
			1 cup oats (6g),
			
			
			1 slice of bread (3g)
			
		
		
			
			Lunch
			
			
			1 cup dal (18g)
			
			
			1 cup rice (4g)
			
			
			200g paneer (14g)
			
			
			1 cup pasta (7g)
			
		
		
			
			Dinner
			
			
			1 chicken (25g)
			
			
			2 chapatis (6g),

			1 cup dal (18g)
			
			
			1 cup lentils (18g)

			1 cup yogurt (8g)
			
			
			1 cup beans (15g)

			1 apple (0.5g)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Plan A

Explanation: Priya's daily protein requirement is approximately 49.8 g. Only dietary plan A meets and exceeds this requirement with 55g of protein among the given options.

  • The Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) is the daily nutrient intake level that meets the needs of nearly all healthy individuals within a specific life stage and gender group. It is designed to guide supervised supplementation for individuals who are deficient or have certain conditions.
  • Based on Indian RDA guidelines, an average Indian adult requires 0.83 grams of protein/kg/day.

Priya's daily protein requirement:

  • Protein requirement = Body weight × Protein requirement per kg
  • Protein requirement = 60 kg × 0.83 g/kg = 49.8 g/day

Evaluating each dietary plan:

  • Option A: Total protein = 12 g + 18 g + 25 g = 55  g
  • Option B: Total protein =1 g + 4 g + 6 g + 18 g = 29  g
  • Option C: Total protein = 6 g + 14 g + 18 g + 8 g = 46  g
  • Option D: Total protein = 3 g + 7 g + 15 g + 0.5 g = 25.5 g

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct energy requirement for a moderately working Indian woman with an exclusively breastfed 8-month-old infant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 2650kcal/day

Explanation:

Total energy requirement for a lactating mother:

  • Total Energy Requirement (TER) = Energy Requirement for Average Woman + Additional Calories for Lactation
  • TER = 2130 kcal/day + 520 kcal/day = 2650 kcal/day

 

  • Total Energy Expenditure (TEE) = Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) x Physical Activity Level (PAL)
  • BMR can be determined using:
    • Double-labeled water method
    • Whole-body calorimeter
    • Factorial approach
  • PAL is the ratio of the energy expenditure over 24 hours to the BMR over the same period.

 

Category

Men

Women

Energy Requirements

Sedentary

2110 kcal/day

1660 kcal/day

Moderate

2710 kcal/day

2130 kcal/day

Heavy

3470 kcal/day

2720 kcal/day

Energy Requirements

Pregnancy

Additional 350 calories

Lactating (0-6m)

Additional 600 calories

Lactating (7-12m)

Additional 520 calories

Energy requirements for elderly (>65 years)

1700 kcal/day

1500 kcal/day

questions.text: What are the Recommended Daily Allowances (RDA) of iron and folate for a pregnant woman?

choices.text: 30 mg/day of iron and 400 mcg/day of folate
27 mg/day of iron and 570 mcg/day of folate
18 mg/day of iron and 600 mcg/day of folate
25 mg/day of iron and 500 mcg/day of folate

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 27 mg/day of iron and 570 mcg/day of folate

Explanation:

The RDA is 27 mg/day of iron and 570 mcg/day of folate. The Tolerable Upper Limit (TUL -maximum daily nutrient intake unlikely to cause adverse health effects) is 45 mg/day for iron and 1000 mcg/day for folate.

The quantity of iron and folic acid in the tablets provided to a pregnant woman under the Anemia Mukt Bharat program is:

  1. 60 mg elemental iron
  2. 500 µg folic acid

questions.text:
A pediatrician is assessing the dietary needs of two infants. One infant is 4 months old and the other is 10 months old. Determine if the following meal plans meet the requirements for each infant:


	Meal Plan of Infant 1 (4 months old): 750 Kcal/day with 9 g of protein
	Meal Plan of Infant 2 (10 months old): 900 Kcal/day with 12 g of protein

choices.text: Both meal plans meet the energy and protein requirements
Infant 1's meal plan exceeds the protein requirement as a percentage of total energy intake.
Infant 2's meal plan exceeds the protein requirement as a percentage of total energy intake.
Neither meal plan meets the energy and protein requirements

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Both meal plans meet the energy and protein requirements

Explanation:

Both meal plans meet the energy and protein requirements for their respective infants. Additionally, the protein percentage of total energy intake is 4.8% for Infant 1 and 5.3% for Infant 2, both well below the 15% threshold.

 

Energy and Protein Requirements for Infants

 

ENERGY

PROTEIN
  • 0-6 months have an estimated energy requirement (EER) of 500-900 kCal/day.
  • 7-12 months have an EER between 650-1100 kCal/day.
  • RDA for protein in infants:
    • 0-6 months old: 8 g/day.
    • 6-12 months old: 10.5 g/day.
  • Protein requirements for infants should not exceed 15% of their total energy.

questions.text: Who among the following is not a beneficiary of ICDS?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Women aged 49 years and above

Explanation:

Women aged 49 years and above are not beneficiaries of ICDS. The beneficiaries of ICDS are mentioned below:

ICDS: Integrated Child Development Services

  • Launched in 1975
  • Aims to develop India’s Human Resource by providing early childhood services
  • Falls under the ministry of woman and child development

Beneficiaries:

  • Pregnant women
  • Nursing mothers
  • Other women 15-45 years
  • Children <3 years
  • Children 3-6 years
  • Adolescent girls 11-18 years

Benefits:

  • Immunisation
  • Health check-up
  • Supplemental nutrition
  • Nutrition and health education
  • Referral services
  • Non-formal preschool education
 

ICDS is implemented through Anganwadi centres.

Nutrition provided

Calories

Protein

Children (6-72 months

500 Kcal

12-15g

Severely Malnourished child (6-72 months)

800kcal

20-25g

Pregnant women and Nursing Mothers

600kcal

18-20g

questions.text: Which of the following is false for Anganwadi centres (AWC)?

choices.text: It is used to run ICDS
AWC can be opened on demand
1 AWC is for every 500-1000 people in plain areas

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1 AWC is for every 500-1000 people in plain areas

Explanation:

1 AWC is for every 400-800 people in plain areas

 

Anganwadi centres (AWC):

AWC

Courtyard through which ICDS is run (Option A)

Capacity
  • Capacity of 1 AWC
    • Plain areas: 400-800 population
    • Hilly areas: 300-800 population
  • Capacity of Mini-AWC: 150-300 population.
  • Anganwadi on demand- in areas with 40 children under 6 years without an AWC.(Option B)

Anganwadi worker (AWW)
  • AWW is the grass root level worker in an AWC
  • Works at field level
  • Education: 10th pass (Option C)
  • Duration of training: 4 months
  • Work:
    • Plain areas: 400-800 population
    • Hilly areas: 300-800 population

Mukhya sevika

Supervises the work of AWWs

Child/Community Development Project Officer (CDPO)

Supervises the overall functioning of ICDS.

1 CDPO can supervise:

  • 1 Block (1,00,000 population)
  • 4 Mukhya sevikas.
  • 100 AWWs

questions.text: Which approach is emphasized under the Anemia Mukt Bharat initiative to combat anemia?

choices.text: Providing free healthcare to pregnant women
Implementing iron and folic acid supplementation programs
Distributing hygiene kits in rural areas

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Implementing iron and folic acid supplementation programs

Explanation:

Anemia Mukt Bharat implements iron and folic acid supplementation as part of one of it interventions.

 

Anemia Mukt Bharat:

  • It follows a 6x6x6 strategy
    • 6 beneficiaries
    • 6 interventions
    • 6 institutional mechanisms
  • Under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MOHFW)
  • Prophylactic Iron and Folic acid supplementation are provided to 6 beneficiaries.
  • Level of prevention: Primary prevention

6 interventions:
  1. Prophylactic iron-folic acid supplementation
  1. Periodic deworming of children, adolescents, pregnant women
  1. Intensified year-round Behavior Change Communication Campaign

(Solid Body, Smart Mind), and ensuring delayed cord clamping
  1. Testing of anemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment
  1. Mandatory provision of iron and folic acid fortified foods in public health programmes
  1. Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia in endemic pockets, with special focus on malaria, haemoglobinopathies and fluorosis.

 

Beneficiaries

Elemental Iron

Folic acid

Schedule

6-59 month

20 mg

100 mcg

Bi-weekly (Syrup)

5-9 years

45 mg

200 mcg

Weekly (Pink tabs)

10-19 years

60 mg

400 mcg

Weekly (Blue tabs)

Reproductive age women

60 mg

400 mcg

Weekly (Red tabs)

Pregnant women

60 mg

400 mcg

Daily (Red tabs)

Lactating

women

60 mg

400 mcg

Daily (Red tabs)

 

6 INTERVENTIONS

6 STRATEGIES
  • Prophylactic iron-folic acid supplementation.
  • Deworming.
  • Intensified year-round behaviour change communication campaign (solid body, smart mind), including ensured delayed cord clamping.
  • Testing of anaemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment.
  • Mandatory provision of iron folic acid fortified foods in public health programmes.
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anaemia in endemic pockets with a special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis.
  • National Anaemia Mukt Bharat Unit.
  • Intra-ministerial coordination.
  • Strengthening supply chain and logistics.
  • Convergence with other ministries.
  • National Centre of Excellence and Advanced Research on Anaemia Control.
  • Anaemia Mukt Bharat dashboard and digital portal- One-stop shop for anaemia.

6 BENEFICIARIES
  • Children, 6-59 months of age.
  • Children, 5-9 years of age.
  • Adolescent girls & boys (10-19 years of age).
  • Women of reproductive age group (20-24 years of age).
  • Pregnant women.
  • Lactating mothers (of 0-6 months child).

questions.text: Which indicator is considered the principal impact indicator in the National Iodine Deficiency Disorders Control Program (NIDDCP), reflecting the effectiveness of salt iodization?

choices.text: Salt iodine content at the production site

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Median urinary iodine levels

 

Explanation:

  • In the NIDDCP, median urinary iodine levels are regarded as the principal impact indicator because they directly reflect the iodine status in the population following salt iodization programs.
  • This indicator is crucial for monitoring the effectiveness of iodine supplementation efforts.

 

National Iodine Deficiency Disorders Control Program (NIDDCP)

Background
  • National Goitre Control Programme (NGCP) launched in 1962 (100% centrally sponsored); NIDDCP launched in 1992

Objectives
  • Supply iodized salt in place of common salt
  • Conduct surveys to assess the magnitude of iodine deficiency disorders (IDD)
  • Resurvey every 5 years to assess IDD extent and iodized salt impact
  • Monitor iodized salt and urinary iodine excretion in labs
  • Provide health education and publicity

Indicators to Monitor Success

Process Indicators
  • Salt iodine content at production site, point of packaging, wholesale and retail levels & in households (Option D)
  • Manufacturing level: ≥30 ppm and Distribution level: ≥15 ppm on a dry weight basis

Impact Indicators
  • Urinary iodine excretion (Principal impact indicator) (Option A)
  • Goitre rate (chronic/long-term impact indicator) (Option B)
  • Neonatal hypothyroidism (sensitive indicator) (Option C)

Sustainability Indicators
  • Median urinary iodine levels in the target population
  • Availability of adequately iodized salt at the household level
  • Set of programmatic indicators

Epidemiological Assessment
  • Prevalence of goitre, cretinism, neonatal hypothyroidism
  • Urinary iodine excretion
  • Measurement of thyroid function (T4, TSH)

Programmatic Goal
  • <5% prevalence of IDD in 10-14 years age group
  • <10% incidence of IDD

Iodized Products

Iodized Oil
  • Intramuscular iodized oil (poppy-seed oil): 1 ml injection provides protection for 4 years
  • Oral iodized oil or sodium iodate tablets effective for 2 years

Iodized Salt
  • Most widely used prophylactic measure against endemic goitre
  • Production level iodization: ≥30 ppm
  • Distribution/consumer level iodization: ≥15 ppm

Two-in-One Salt
  • Developed by NIN (Hyderabad) as Double Fortified Salt (DFS)
  • Contains salt, potassium iodate, ferrous sulphate, sodium hexametaphosphate
  • Provides 40 mcg iodine and 1 mg iron per gram of salt

questions.text: What is the primary objective of the Kishori Shakti Yojana?

choices.text: Promoting higher education among adolescent girls
Ensuring maternal healthcare for pregnant women
Empowering adolescent girls through nutrition and health education
Providing financial assistance for marriage expenses

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Empowering adolescent girls through nutrition and health education

Explanation:

Kishori Shakti Yojana aims to empower adolescent girls through nutrition and health education.

  • Part of the existing ICDS scheme
  • Targets adolescent girls 11-18 years
  • Provides education on health, hygiene, and nutrition
  • Encourages girls to be in school

  • Promoting higher education among adolescent girls. (Option A): While education is part of the broader goal, the primary objective of Kishori Shakti Yojana (KSY) focuses more on health, nutrition, and empowerment, not specifically higher education.

  • Ensuring maternal healthcare for pregnant women (Option B): This is outside the scope of KSY, which targets adolescent girls, not pregnant women.

  • Providing financial assistance for marriage expenses (Option D): KSY does not provide funds for marriage. Its goal is to delay early marriage and improve overall wellbeing.

questions.text: What is the main focus of the Pradhan Mantri Poshan Scheme launched by the Government of India?

choices.text: Empowering women through nutrition development programs
Providing financial assistance for rural agricultural development

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Improving nutritional outcomes among children

Explanation:

Pradhan mantri Poshan Sheme

  • Formerly known as mid-day meal scheme
  • Under the ministry of education
  • Aims to prevent school dropouts and provide nutrition for children
  • Rolled out in government schools
  • For preschoolers up till class 8
  • Primary- 450 kcal, 12 gm protein
  • Upper primary- 700 kcal, 20 gm protein

POSHAN Abhiyan:

  • PM's Overarching Scheme for Holistic Nourishment
  • Also known as the National Nutrition Mission
  • Launched in 2018 by the Ministry of Women & Child Development.

Targets:

  • Reduce low birth weight (<2.5 kg) by 2% annually.
  • Decrease stunting (chronic malnutrition) by 2% annually.
  • Lower underweight (acute on chronic malnutrition) by 2% annually.
  • Reduce anemia by 3% annually.

 

 Empowering women through nutrition development programs (Option A): Though women (e.g., cooks, SHGs) are involved in implementation, the scheme is not focused on empowering women directly. Empowering women via nutrition falls more under schemes like POSHAN Abhiyaan. Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana. PM POSHAN is child-centric, not women-centric.

 Promoting sustainable agriculture practices (Option C): Sustainable agriculture is covered under schemes like Paramparagat Krishi Vikas Yojana (PKVY). National Mission for Sustainable Agriculture (NMSA). PM POSHAN has no direct link to agricultural practices. Nutrition delivery is the goal, not agricultural development.

Providing financial assistance for rural agricultural development (Option D): This pertains to schemes such as PM-KISAN (income support to farmers). Rural Infrastructure Development Fund (RIDF). PM POSHAN does not provide financial aid for agriculture. It is about feeding children, not financing rural agriculture.

questions.text:
Match the logos with their appropriate description

 


	
		
			
			LOGO
			
			
			DESCRIPTION
			
		
		
			
			 

			(A)
			
			
			1. Affiliated to a department that comes under the Ministry of Consumer affairs
			
		
		
			
			 

			(B) 
			
			
			2. Regulated by the Ministry of Food Processing Industries
			
		
		
			
			 

			(C) 
			
			
			3. Affiliated with the Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers Welfare
			
		
		
			
			 

			(D)
			
			
			4. Affiliated to a department that comes under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  B) A-4 B-1 C-2 D-3

Explanation:

LOGO

DESCRIPTION

 

(A)
  • Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI)
  • Headquarters: New Delhi
  • Ministry: Health and Family Welfare
  • Provides national food standards for products
  • Adopts standards from CODEX ALIMENTARIUS by WHO and FAO (WHO Headquarters: Geneva; FAO Headquarters: Rome)
  • Recently launched the Eat Right Campaign




 

 

(B)
  • Bureau of Indian Standards
  • Ministry: Ministry of Consumer affairs
  • PFA (Prevention of Food Adulteration) provides the Minimum quality of food products.
  • BIS provides quality above the minimum standards of food products.

 

(C)
  • Fruit Product/Process Order.
  • The Ministry of Food Processing Industries has created an online system for licensing and monitoring all activities related to the enforcement and administration of FPO.
  • Regulates the quality of tinned fruit juices and tinned fruit cans.


 

 

(D)
  • This is administered by the Directorate of Marketing and Inspection (DMI) under the Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers Welfare for agricultural products.
  • AGMARK is a certification mark indicating that agricultural produce meets a grade standard specified by DMI
